xxl.cursors
Class Sequentializer

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--xxl.cursors.Sequentializer
public class Sequentializer
extends Object
implements Cursor

A Sequentializer concatenates n input-Cursors to a single Cursor.

Note: The input-Iterator or input-PeekIterator array is wrapped to a Cursor array. Further the contained input-Iterators or input-Iterators of this array are wrapped to Cursors. If these Cursors do not support the peek-functionality they will finally be wrapped to BufferedCursors, so the peek-functionality is guaranteed.

The field cursor is set in the method hasNext to the next input-Iterator as follows: 

 	while (!cursor.hasNext() && iteratorsCursor.hasNext()) {
 		Iterator iterator = (Iterator)iteratorsCursor.next();
The method returns the next element of the current used cursor, i.e. cursor.hasNext() is called.
A field named updateCursor is used to reference the current cursor with regard to remove or update operations. This cursor is set in the next or peek method.
So a Sequentializer sets the field cursor to the first input-Iterator and returns this cursor using lazy evaluation, then the cursor is set to the next input-Iterator and so on.
The user can specify two Iterators to be sequentialized or even an array of Iterators. Further a constructor takes one Iterator and a parameterless Function is invokedto determine the second Iterator to be sequentialized.
Other constructors use Cursors or Iterators of Iterators, i.e. each element returned by such a Cursor or Iterator is an Iterator.

Example usage (1): 

 	Sequentializer sequentializer = new Sequentializer(
 		new Enumerator(11),
 		new Enumerator(11, 21)
 	);
 	while(sequentializer.hasNext())
 		System.out.print(sequentializer.next() +"; ");
 	System.out.flush(); System.out.println();
This instance of a Sequentializer concatenates the two given Enumerators. The first Enumerator contains the elements 0, ...,10. The second Enumerator contains the elements 11, ...,20. So the result of the completely consumed Sequentializer is a ascending sequence with range [0,20].

Example usage (2): 

 	sequentializer = new Sequentializer(
 		new Enumerator(1,4),
 		new Function () {
 			public Object invoke () {
 				return new Enumerator(4,7);
 			}
 		}
 	);
 	while(sequentializer.hasNext())
 		System.out.print(sequentializer.next() +"; ");
 	System.out.flush(); System.out.println();
This instance of a Sequentializer concatenates the three elements of the first Enumerator (1, 2, 3) with the elements of the second Enumerator determined by the defined function. So the output printed to the output stream is: 
 	1; 2; 3; 4; 5; 6;

Example usage (3): 

 	sequentializer = new Sequentializer(
 		new HashGrouper(
 			new Enumerator(21),
 			new Function () {
 				public Object invoke (Object next) {
 					return new Integer(((Integer)next).intValue() % 5);
 				}
 			}
 		)
 	);
 	while(sequentializer.hasNext())
 		System.out.print(sequentializer.next() +"; ");
 	System.out.flush(); System.out.println();
This example demonstrates the Sequentializer's concatentation using a constructor that receives a Cursor of Cursors as paramater. The used HashGrouper is a Cursor and each elements of this Cursor points to a a group of the used HashMap, realized as a Cursor. The elements of the Enumerator are inserted in the buckets of the HashMap by applying the given Function on them. So the buckets with keys 0, ..., 4 remain and are filled up. For further details see HashGrouper.
Now the Sequentializer takes these buckets (cursors) and concatenates them.
So the output is: 


 	4; 9; 14; 19; 3; 8; 13; 18; 2; 7; 12; 17; 1; 6; 11; 16; 0; 5; 10; 15; 20;

See Also:
Iterator, Constant, Function, Cursor

Field Detail

iteratorsCursor

protected Cursor iteratorsCursor
The input-Cursor containg the input-Iterators.

cursor

protected Cursor cursor
The current used cursor of the input-Cursor iteratorsCursor which contains the input-Iterators.
The constructors set this cursor to a new EmptyCursor().
This cursor is set in the method hasNext to the next input-Iterator as follows: 

 	while (!cursor.hasNext() && iteratorsCursor.hasNext()) {
 		Iterator iterator = (Iterator)iteratorsCursor.next();

 	cursor = iterator instanceof Cursor?
 		(Cursor)iterator:
 		iterator instanceof PeekIterator?
 			(Cursor)new PeekIteratorCursor((PeekIterator)iterator):
 			(Cursor)new IteratorCursor(iterator);
The input-Iterator is also wrapped to a Cursor.

updateCursor

protected Cursor updateCursor
The cursor that is used concerning a remove or update method. This cursor is set in the next or peek method.

                      Function function)

Parameters:
iterator - first input-Iterator.
function - parameterless function returning the second input-Iterator on demand. This function is invoked after the first input-Iterator has been processed completely.

Method Detail

close

public void close()
           throws UnsupportedOperationException
This method is not supported by Sequentializers.
If this method is called an UnsupportedOperationException is thrown.
Specified by:
close in interface Cursor
Throws:
UnsupportedOperationException - if the close operation is not supported the Sequentializer.

hasNext

public boolean hasNext()
Returns true if the iteration has more elements.
(In other words, returns true if next or peek would return an element rather than throwing an exception.)
The field cursor is set in this method to the next input-Iterator as follows: 

 	while (!cursor.hasNext() && iteratorsCursor.hasNext()) {
 		Iterator iterator = (Iterator)iteratorsCursor.next();

 	cursor = iterator instanceof Cursor?
 		(Cursor)iterator:
 		iterator instanceof PeekIterator?
 			(Cursor)new PeekIteratorCursor((PeekIterator)iterator):
 			(Cursor)new IteratorCursor(iterator);
The input-Iterator is also wrapped to a Cursor. If this cursor does not support the peek-functionality it is also wrapped to a BufferedCursor.
The method returns the next element of the current used cursor, i.e. cursor.hasNext() is called.
Specified by:
hasNext in interface Cursor
Returns:
true if the Sequentializer has more elements.

next

public Object next()
            throws NoSuchElementException
Returns the next element in the iteration.
This element will be removed from the underlying collection, if next is called.
Returns cursor.next() and sets updateCursor = cursor.
Specified by:
next in interface Cursor
Returns:
the next element in the iteration.
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - iteration has no more elements.

peek

public Object peek()
            throws NoSuchElementException,
                   UnsupportedOperationException
Shows the next element in the iteration without removing it from the underlying collection. (optional operation)
Returns cursor.peek() and sets updateCursor = cursor.
Specified by:
peek in interface Cursor
Returns:
the next element in the iteration.
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - iteration has no more elements.
UnsupportedOperationException - if the peek operation is not supported by the this Sequentializer. (not possible)

remove

public void remove()
            throws IllegalStateException,
                   UnsupportedOperationException
Removes from the underlying collection the last element returned by the Sequentializer. (optional operation)
This method can be called only once per call to next or peek.
The behavior of a Sequentializer is unspecified if the underlying collection is modified while the iteration is in progress in any way other than by calling this method.
Tests if the field updateCursor is null then a remove operation is not possible because there exists no current used cursor where the last returned element can be removed and an IllegalStateException is thrown. Else updateCursor.remove() is called and updateCursor is set to null.
Specified by:
remove in interface Cursor
Throws:
UnsupportedOperationException - if the remove operation is not supported by this Sequentializer.
IllegalStateException - if the next or peek method has not yet been called, or the remove method has already been called after the last call to the next or peek method.

reset

public void reset()
           throws UnsupportedOperationException
This method is not supported by Sequentializers. (optional operation)
If this method is called an UnsupportedOperationException is thrown.
Specified by:
reset in interface Cursor
Throws:
UnsupportedOperationException - if the reset method is not supported by this Sequentializer.

supportsPeek

public boolean supportsPeek()
Returns true if the peek-operation is supported by this Sequentializer.
Else returns false.
Returns true, because every input-Iterator is wrapped to a BufferedCursor.
Specified by:
supportsPeek in interface Cursor
Returns:
true if the peek operation is supported by this Sequentializer.

update

public void update(Object object)
            throws IllegalStateException,
                   UnsupportedOperationException
Replaces the object that was returned by the last call to next or peek. (optional operation)
This operation must not be called after a call to hasNext. It should follow a call to next or peek.
This method should be called only once per call to next or peek.
The behavior of a Sequentializer is unspecified if the underlying collection is modified while the iteration is in progress in any way other than by calling this method.
Tests if the field updateCursor is null then an update is not possible because there exists no current used cursor where the last returned element can be updated and an IllegalStateException is thrown. Else updateCursor.update(object) is called and updateCursor is set to null.
Specified by:
update in interface Cursor
Parameters:
object - the object that replaces the object returned by the last call to next or peek.
Throws:
IllegalStateException - if the next or peek method has not yet been called, or the update method has already been called after the last call to the next or peek method.
UnsupportedOperationException - if the update operation is not supported by this Sequentializer.

main

public static void main(String[] args)
The main method contains some examples to demonstrate the usage and the functionality of this class.
Parameters:
args - array of String arguments. It can be used to submit parameters when the main method is called.
